justification: "Ultimately, the memory bias is quantified by the strength of preference for remembered over forgotten options" obtained during the remember-and-decide task.
Participants "performed the estimate-your-memory task, in which they indicated how well they remembered each possible item"—providing a direct measure of perceived memory strength.
In the gambling task, participants "made binary decisions between a sure gain or loss and a risky ... lottery," and the resulting choices were modeled to extract individual risk-attitude parameters.
The same gambling task included trials where probability information was occluded; choices in these "ambiguous" lotteries were modeled to derive individual ambiguity-attitude parameters.
"Participants' subjective value of the images was assessed with an incentivized rating task... Participants rated the images on a discrete rating scale ranging from -10 to 10."
